intro: Psilotrichum spicatum, commonly known as the spicate field spikerush, is a member of the Sphagnum family and is characterized by its dense, spiky growth form. It typically thrives in wet, acidic environments such as bogs and marshes, where it plays a crucial role in nutrient cycling. The plant has a simple morphology with a central stem and leaf-like structures called phyllodes, which are arranged in a spiral pattern. Its reproductive structures, known as sporangia, are borne on specialized stems called spicules, which give the plant its common name. Psilotrichum spicatum is an important component of peat-forming ecosystems and contributes to the preservation of wetland habitats.
